thread.title: Performance cars descend on Waitara for annual street-race
thread.title_full: Performance cars descend on Waitara for annual street-race

author: Jeremy Wilkinson
title: Performance cars descend on Waitara for annual street-race
text:
Performance cars descend on Waitara for annual street-race JEREMY WILKINSON Last updated 14:24, February 18 2017 Jeremy Wilkinson 
Inside a car for the 3rd Annual Waitara Street Sprint, run by the Taranaki Car Club. 
A decade ago Danny Picard's 1996 Mitsubishi Mirage cost him $1500 to buy when he was 15 - now it's had more than $60,000 worth of upgrades done to it. 
They're not just for show though, and Picard has the skills to match his performance vehicle as he was leading the pack of 54 drivers entered in the annual Waitara Street Sprints on Saturday morning. 
"I won't get in the car with him," dad John said, "I just build the thing, he can do the racing." SUPPLIED 
Drivers were handling the wet conditions well. 
Though with a light drizzle persevering through Saturday morning drivers were taking it easy on the greasy road and only a few ended up hitting the hay bales placed on the extra-tight turns. 
READ MORE: 
Picard travelled from Wellington for the event, one of a handful of drivers from outside of Taranaki, and said the trick to driving on wet roads in a sprint-race was the same as on a public road. SUPPLIED 
Drivers had to do two laps of a roughly one-kilometre circuit around Pukekohe Domain in Waitara. 
"Just total control. Drive to the conditions and hope like hell you don't hit a hay bale." 
Dave Geraghty - driving a 1992 Mitsubishi Lancer - has won the street race once in it's now three-year history - and said his secret was knowing his car. 
"I've had it for 14 years, I bought it after a breakup and thought I needed to treat myself," he said. SUPPLIED 
Danny Picard's car, a 96 Mirage Coup, was $1500 when he bought it 10 years ago. It's worth a fair bit more now. 
"When you've had a car that long you just know how it handles, you know how to drive it. Ad Feedback 
"It's my baby." 
Geraghty was sitting just behind Picard early on with a time of 2m18s for the two laps each car gets around the roughly 1km circuit around Pukekohe Domain in Waitara. SUPPLIED 
Dave Geraghty with his "baby" a '92 Mitsubishi Lancer he's had for 14 years. 
The event is run by the Taranaki Car Club and committee member Scotty Smith said Waitara was "probably the best place to hold it". 
"The locals just love it, they come out in force to watch," he said. 
Testament to Smith's word locals lined the streets of the circuit, heedless of the rain, admiring the speed at which cars of all shapes and sizes covered the usually 50kmh speed limited streets. SUPPLIED 
A few cars suffered mishaps with the wet weather. 
"They can get up to about 160kmh along the main straight," Smith said. 
"But even though there's an overall winner they're mainly competing for a bit of fun, and of course bragging rights." 
It's become a popular event, he said, and now it even has a waiting list. SUPPLIED 
Competitors eagerly check their times to see if they've made it to the next round. 
"There's not many opportunities round the country to drive on public roads like this. 
"We're just lucky to get the council on board and have a community like Waitara so keen to have it here." 
Sister duo Rebecca and Brooke Ray were driving a hot-pink Volkswagen Polo and driver Brooke said the key to handling the greasy roads was to "take your time". SUPPLIED 
Driver Brooke Ray and co-driver Rebecca Ray were handling the wet conditions well. 
"That's nonsense," co-pilot Rebecca said, "If in doubt flood it out. Just plant your foot."
